greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(1) = 2, a(2) = 3; for n >= 2, a(n+1) is largest prime factor of (Product_{k=1..n} a(k)) - 1.
comment: Like the Euclid-Mullin sequence A000946, but subtracting rather than adding 1 to the product.
example: a(4)=29 since 2*3*5=30 and 29 is the largest prime factor of 30-1
a(5)=79 since 2*3*5*29=870 and 79 is the largest prime factor of 870-1=869=11*79.
results.author: _Marc LeBrun_, May 31 2003
ext: More terms from _Hugo Pfoertner_, May 31, 2003, using Dario Alpern's ECM.
The next term a(15) is not known. It requires the factorization of the 245-digit composite number which remains after eliminating 7 smaller factors.
